The alternative set of jobs implies that all fips jobs should inherit from this, or have to call enable-fips themselves.
The former is unmanageable, because often we want to take an existing job and enable fips on it, and reparenting and recreating the hierarchy is not an option.
The latter is what we have being doing so far, with a copy of a simple playbook copied in each and every repository. I believe and advocated for a long time that copying the same code over and over is an unneeded complication.

So the question is: with enable_fips disabled by default, would it still possible to always call the fips role in the pre phase of the topmost openstack job, so that we don't need to either create a double hierarchy or have an enable-fips playbook in all repositories?
I see, thanks, I've missed the other review. That would simplify the testing a lot.

What we've been doing so far has worked because we have not had to deal with trying to access a secret (the ua subscription key) that is stored in project-config.

Up to now, we've only implemented fips jobs on centos, where this is not an issue.

In order to access the secret - and also to make sure that the fips playbooks happen very early in the process, we need to add the alternative job here.  The idea is to change the parent job very early in the hierarchy, so that all subsequent jobs inherit the ability to enable fips.

An example of this is here:  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/devstack/+/871606

With this change, all jobs descended from devstack-base will have the ability to enable fips simply by specifying enable_fips:True and specifying a nslookup_target.

So, yes, what you said is what is planned -- to always call the fips role in the pre phase of the topmost openstack job - through inheritance.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Apologies for the lag in review on this one - I needed to step back and think about what problem we're trying to solve with the storage for a bootstrapped flag.

I think we're trying to limit the execution of a few pieces of code that need to be run once-ish (see below).  DB sync would be one of them - but the lead unit does this and sets a 'ready' flag on the peer relation to signal other units that this activity has been completed.  The other seems to be around the bootstrap status state - but we might want to refactor that anyway.

I say once-ish because in fact its not once; we need to re-sync the database on every charm refresh as this may involve a new set of resource versions which could be a new openstack release, or just a new set of updates - either of which may involve a db change of some description.

Using the units data bag on the peer relation would prevent that from happening; using stored state that is not persisted to the controller might have a more desirable behaviour, as a charm refresh would clear the prior state and trigger any run-once per pod instantiation type behaviours we need.  The other side effect of using the peer relation is that every time something gets set, we get a set of hooks executing that don't actually do anything - this seems inefficient.

That said I'm unsure about how leadership changes during a stateful set refresh - so we'd need to consider that as well.

I'm sorry I though I pushed the reply button, it was just saved in the draft. But Alex's explaination is correct.

Upgrading the charm gives the following path so far :
upgrade-hook trigger --> bash script --> exec upgrade-charm.real --> __main__ of python being run -- X --> fails to find the hook upgrade-charm.real

In __main__, there is this command   "hooks.execute(sys.argv)", which is basically "please run a hook with the same name as the file".
But so far there was no hook named upgrade-charm.real.
Only @hooks.hook('upgrade-charm') can be found, which is why on line 774 I modified the name of the hook to be correctly from the Bash script

INFO unit.rabbit-focal/0.juju-log server.go:316 Unknown hook upgrade-charm.real - skipping.

I've done it the same way that it's done for other packages.
e.g.: https://opendev.org/starlingx/integ/src/branch/master/python/python3-setuptools/debian/meta_data.yaml

I don't think that a sha256sum is applicable here since there are 3 files that are downloaded from that URL:
python3.9_3.9.2-1.stx.1.debian.tar.xz
python3.9_3.9.2-1.stx.1.dsc
python3.9_3.9.2.orig.tar.xz
OK, so the .dsc files in the archive contain signatures that are used to confirm the packages.

dget does the checksum after downloading, like

python3.9_3.9.2-1.dsc:
      Good signature found
   validating python3.9_3.9.2.orig.tar.xz
   validating python3.9_3.9.2-1.debian.tar.xz
All files validated successfully.

or does the checksum if the files exist, if the checksum is incorrect, it re-downloads the files, so don't need extra checksum here.

" archive (needed by Debian native package) - Contains the download url of the .dsc, .orig.tar.xx, .debian.tar.xx of a Debian native package. The url link is end with the last folder name, not specific file. An example meta_data.yaml."  - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/StarlingX/DebianBuildStructure

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This patch does multiple things:
1) extends the virt interface to to pass share_info down to the driver an update the signatures in all in tree drivers
2) extends the compute manager to pass the share_info to the driver at certain actions
3) implement the share_info handling in the libvirt driver
3.1) checks requirements for shares and reports the new capabilities to signal that
3.2) extends the config handling for virtio mounts
3.3) implements mount / unmount
4) changes the scheduler to request new capabilities

In the future you can try to split patches along these lines to help the reviewer.

I totally agree. I did that patch early after arriving on the team.
And at that moment, it was difficult for me to understand the "full picture". So I ended up writing large patches.
I sincerely apologize for this, as it makes the review difficult.
In more recent patches, I learned, and now I tend to split stuff better and reduce the size of patches.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Question on the background of the issue: When does this situation happens? A port needs to be visible when associating the port to a floating IP, so I am wondering what kind of operations leads to such situation.

I still wonder how such floating IP associations were created. When associating an internal port with a floating IP, a tenant needs to see the internal port to be associated. This means that a port associated with a floating IP of tenant A needs to be visible to tenant A, but what you explained is totally different. In my understanding, only exception is that admin associated FIP with an internal port.

I am not necessarily against adding a workaround but I would like to clarify how such situation happens to maintain the code.

In this case, the customer had a bunch of floating IPs that were assigned to some fixed ip ports owned by another tenant so iterating over the floating ips works but getting the details of which instance ID it's attached to is unavailable and returns a "no such ports found" ... as admin, we see all fixed ips as well as which instance those IPs are bound to but not all users can see all ports/vms so this breaks in horizon but not in neutron CLI.

No that works as expected but if the floating IP is from ANOTHER tenant , it won't be able to show the port information because neutron retourns a 404.     This happens probably if you have a shared floating IP network with multiple tenant able to assign a public IP to a fixed IP.  Tenant A can't list Tenant B ... this is expected.

> if the floating IP is from ANOTHER tenant,

I am confused with this clause.
The logic you touch is part of FloatingIPManager. _set_instance_info() method is called from list(), get(), and allocate() methods. Floating IPs are only visible from a same tenant (or a superuser like "admin" role), If a floating IP is from another´tenant, the floating IP is not visible to the current tenant.
neutron does not provide a way to share a floating IP to another tenant.

In addition, when a port is associated with a floating IP, the port associated needs to be visible to a tenant who owns the floating IP.

Considering the above two, I am still not sure why the case you mention happens.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I just fixed the indentation.

I would like to understand how this happens. In neutron, a user needs to have a permission to get a port to associate the port with a floating IP. My question is how you associated such port with a floating IP.
Did you associate a port with a floating IP using more powerful user permission like admin?

A floating IP cannot be assocaited with an unaccessable port unless admin does it.
That's the reason I would like to clarify the situation. I am afraid there is a bug in neutron as a corner case and horizon hides it.

There many other possibilities. This is not static system. The port might have been accessible at the moment of assigning, but since then the policies might have been changed, for example. Or it could have been modified otherwise. Even if admin did it, that is still a valid case that we should handle. Horizon's responsibility is not to be a validator for Neutron's database. There is a separate Validations project that could handle this.

Whether the situation is "normal" or not, what else would you propose we do when this error happens? Skipping the port we don't have access to seems to be the best possibility, surely better than failing altogether.

manila/network/neutron/neutron_network_p.message: can this be done after identifying the VLAN i.e. after line 472?

no, it is the exactly the purpose of creating the port binding on the target host. Until port binding created, the neutron network segment associated with the physical network, which the target host is connected to, is not guaranteed to be allocated, i.e. the segment is created only when needed. Of course, if some port from the bespoken neutron network already exists on that physical network, the segment would be existing. But that is not guaranteed. So creating the port binding should come before identifying the VLAN

/COMMIT_MSG.message: how was calibration for this timeout determined? (From comment for Fix: above, it appears fixing the typo on 'statefullsets' was not sufficient)

The pod rollout script was changed to return error when this timeout is reached, so it should ever be reached under normal circumstances. However, it is not possible determine how much time the rollout will need, because, for example, a valid user case is the user's deploy being composed by slow machines overcrowded with deployments/daemonsets/statefulsets with implementations that causes the pod restart to be slow. It was observed in a DC deploy with WRA and in slower vbox deploys with some apps that the rollout process was getting closer to the previous timeout (8 minutes), so the timeout was increased to avoid reporting false errors. The 30 minutes was thought as an amount of time that should never be reached but, at same time, an amount of time that is reasonable to give the operator a feedback about the pod rollout status. Typically, the script will spend around 5 minutes in execution.

into the targets as a wwpn and have it work as a useful redirect.  Plus, we're creating the main part of the path ourselves at line 68, so even if someone were able to get some kind of crazy host_device field into the hba, it looks like it would be surrounded by enough other characters that you wouldn't be able to make the system do anything.  So I think this is pretty unlikely as an attack vector (but then I'm not sufficiently devious to be a good hacker).  But by putting the nosec here we are saying that this is definitely not an attack vector.

tempest/lib/common/http.py.message:
huhh this makes the return type depend on a flag. But I see you documented this on  higher levels so it I won't block on it. 

Maybe a better API would be to always do preload_content = False, return the raw object, and let the caller force the load by reading the data. But I know that it would affect all places using a GET request so that would be a very disruptive change.

Yeah, it's also unfortunate that there are so many layers in general (although I know why), and I also think it's kind of unfortunate that we're returning something that is supposed to look like the HTTPResponse, but in dict form. It took me a minute to realize that we're not actually returning the response itself to tests. At the very least, in this case we're returning the real type that the dict is based off of, so in reality, it's not very different and a bunch of code in between actually doesn't notice.

Until the recent type annotation enforcement craze, Python used to be all about duck typing :)

octavia_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/v2.message: This change adds 228 new round trips to the backend member servers from this patch alone. Do we really need that many to prove functionality?

I don't know if I understood this comment correctly 😕

In check_members_balanced the default value for repeat is 20, so I imagine that the comment is not related to the "repeat=19" but for the new amount of tests. But I think are more, before this patch we only evaluate ROUND_ROBIN for the 3 protocols (http, tcp and udp), each of those test call to _test_healthmonitor_traffic and each one of them call check_members_balanced 3 times so 3x3x20=120 checks, now we do the same for the other 3 additional lb_algorithms supported so 4x3x3x19=684 checks (just in case the driver support the four algorithms). IMHO now we have 100% coverage, and before it we have 25%.

octavia_tempest_plugin/tests/validators..message: I ran "tox -eall -- test_healthmonitor_" but it seems the code never entered this branch. I didn't debug it further, but that seems wrong to me.

Yeah, due to the default value for the "repeat=20" that branch was not evaluated, I add some odd number of request to some calls to this function to ensure the branch is evaluated and complete for future use. Thx for the review
Thanks. I wanted to understand how this works as it looks a bit complex. Now that I tested it I think self.assertTrue(max(response_values) - min(response_values) <= 1) would be cleaner.

:) But you proposal doesn't validate that the values are circular order. Let me sumarize with an example of responses_by_member (four members):

If the responses_by_members will be as [3,2,3,2] would be pass for your proposal, but this is not a valid circular order for a round-robin algorithm. So that was the main motivation to compare with the next member and check == or +=1 as valid options, ensuring for the same example a pattern [3,3,2,2]

I guess this method implied it was "balanced".
I'm not sure this change is needed.

This method will fail for any algorithm other than round_robin, it was not tested for not ideal cases for round_robin. It was checking just that all the members have the same number of request, and this hipotesis is just valid for a round_robin algorithm when the repeat % number_members == 0, that check will fail over algorithms with random balancing or fixed dest (source_ip)

But with the added lines for the case of round_robin (in particular the else) we are ensuring the circular iteration over the members ensuring that if we have 4 members (and 19 requests) we will have a requests response pattern as (5,5,5,4)

I hope I have made myself clear 😊

glanceclient/v1/images.py.message: Why not reuse this documentation? It is a little more verbose, but conveys more information about the parameter.

Could you please explain why we need to get rid of named constant here?
I think it is good to have this constant defined in one place instead of "spreading" the hard-coded constant through functions.

I am sorry but I am tend to disagree. 
1) Unfortunately there is no 100% guarantee that this code will be changed one day. IMO it always can happen with the code and best approach to this is to be prepared for changed. One day somebody can introduce new openstack request id header.
2) Not using named constants is not convention IMO. It is just bad practice and we should refactor the code one day to change these hard-coded constants. Named constant in theory should provide some abstraction instead of concentrating on value (and understanding why do we need this constant, what does it mean and so on). So it allows not to bother at value at all which is pretty good and readable. 
Perhaps, the constant name is not good that's why you consider it as not readable.
Sorry to sound like a holly war guy:), but I think the point does worth it:)

I'm happy either way here, tbh. IMHO, this variable should either go away or be made private. Lets remember that glanceclient is not just a CLI and this is the library that we're talking about. This means someone could just change the value of this "constant".

So, again, either we make it private or we remove it. Either are good with me. I'll let someone else, with a stronger opinion, to chime in.

That said, I'm not in favor of creating a gazillion of global constants in a "constants.py" module. My point is that we already have this one an making it private or removing it is fine by me.

Due to the stability drive on OpenStack APIs the header key will not change. Being consistent we do not use named constants for our paths nor other header keys either. Utilizing the value that will stay constant is just way more descriptive and reader friendly than all caps name which tries to mimic the value.

No war, I'm happy to agree to disagree, that sed line to change the header name will not change regardless if it's in multiple constants through the project files or written open into the code so it has nothing to do with future proofing. Just readability and consistency, which of I'm huge fan.

Removing making the code not supportable. Instead of gazillion constants we have much more literals that need to be supported every time it changes.
I think this direction is not so right.

if max share size is 100 gb, max share extend size should be 150gb. This allows user to extend the share if its already created with max share size limit. However, this extend limit would again possibly ignored by admin i.e. admin can extend share to even 200gb or max value supported by provider

playbooks/enable-fips/README.rst.message: This sentence seems contradictory now. If it defaults to true, a job shouldn't need to set it at all (unless a parent job has set it to false, I guess?).

playbooks/enable-fips/pre.yaml.message: This is a backward-incompatible change in the role, which we'll probably want to announce on the zuul-announce ML. Now any jobs which add it will need to also enable it.

For the enable_fips parameter, there is another approach that may be more palatable.

We could do the following:
1) leave the parameter as defaulting to true here, so as not to break any non-openstack zuul users.

2) override the parameter by setting enable_fips to False in openstack-multinode-fips

That way, any jobs that inherit from openstack-multinode-fips will need to explicitly override enable_fips and set it to true to opt into FIPS mode.

This gets us the behavior we want in OpenStack, and also doesn't break any non-OpenStack zuul users.

Will that work?

Thanks for digging in, Ian.  Its important to discuss the details to make the decisions being made clear.

Because enabling FIPS requires a reboot, we need to run the fips playbook and reboot very, very early in the process.  In particular, for the multinode job,we need to complete the reboot and fully come up again before all the networking and other multinode setup is done.  Doing it afterwards has led to inconsistent results.

That means that FIPS jobs need to inherit from a base job where FIPS is enabled very early in the inheritance stack, and it isn't just a matter of adding on a playbook to run at the end.

We can (and in fact, had) created such a base job for tripleO (multinode-fips).  Originally the idea there was to have all the tripleO jobs simply run in FIPS mode.  But we quickly found that some jobs (those that build some components) didn't work under FIPS, and so we created the flag as an escape hatch for those jobs.

In practice, though, because changes in centos-stream (for components like gnutls etc.) made fips jobs unstable, tripleo ended up explicitly setting enable_fips in most jobs.  The flag was also useful in that we were able to set it to False temporarily while we worked through the centos FIPS issues.

We want to be able to create FIPS jobs for all openstack projects - and doing it right means executing the FIPS  pre.yaml early in the process in a base job.  One way to do this is to create a whole parallel stack of jobs that inherit from openstack-multinode-fips.  In this case, it makes sense that the flag is set to true by default.  This approach seems unmanageable to me.

The other way we can do this is to change all the openstack jobs to inherit from openstack-multinode-fips, so that the fips pre.yaml is in fact included in every job.  In this case, the purpose of the flag is changed.  It becomes, as you noted, a global that is available to allow all openstack jobs to opt into fips.

This seems like the only workable approach to me, and is what is implemented in this patch.  A follow-up patch would update the openstack jobs that inherit from multinode to inherit from openstack-multinode-fips instead.

If we agree with the approach, I can:
1) modify the commit message to reflect everything I just mentioned above
2) send a message to zuul-announce to announce the change in the flag. 

What do you think?
This does seem like an odd change?  Why swap this default?  If you've called enable-fips it seems like you want to ... enable fips?

OK, so the idea *is* to basically install this in the early path of every job and have the flag be able to be toggled on.  That's fine, but most of the informational part of the above comment could be in the changelog to explain this.

In this case, I'd agree that keeping this default(false) is actually the logical choice here.  

I'd like to see the role README.rst updated to explain that this role is intended to be run very early and in all playbooks, and needs to be explicitly enabled via variables, and describe that with the standard ..zuul:rolevar tags.  Basically what was explained above 😊

OK, AFAICS, this pre.yaml is only included in the multinode-fips and fips-unittest jobs [1].  this makes sense.

It seems a bit weird to even have this enable/disable flag here.  To include this you have to parent to a -fips job (per above) so you must want fips enabled ...

After some digging on the original change I guess this came from [2] where, if I'm understanding, basically all the tripleo jobs were parented to the fips-multinode jobs, but fips needed to be disabled on one of those jobs due to issues?  So we grew this flag, it seems...

So it *maybe* makes sense to have this flag like this if the idea is to include this pre.yaml in *every* job, and have fips as an opt-in flag available globally.  But that's not how it works, and the changelog here also suggests that enabling fips is still a process of parenting yourself to the fips jobs.  So it doesn't seem we're proposing to make it global...

Honestly, the original purpose of having this as an escape hatch so that you can parent to fips jobs but not actually enable fips seems a bit like a foot-gun ... it just opens a window for forgetting that you've set the "actually fips is disabled on this test" job.  So I'd question it's validity ... but even so I can't see any reason why this wouldn't be "true" in this context anyway.

Sorry, a long review over a small flag -- but I think it affects the usability of this sufficient to clarify what's going on.  

[1] https://codesearch.opendev.org/?q=enable-fips%2Fpre.yaml&i=nope&literal=nope&files=&excludeFiles=&repos=
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ci/+/814648/1/zuul.d/content-provider.yaml

specs for reference - https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila-specs/+/330306

After merge of manila backup spec, updating PR to address spec comments.

FYI, Steps to test on devstack :-
1. Create share of 1 GB. e.g. name it tmp_backup. Export location of share (admin) is then added in /manila/data/drivers/nfs.py config option 'backup_share'. e.g. 10.1.1.100:/shares/share-5c8bba9f-18ad-4e64-801e-204575e7a97a
2. Add host IP in manila/data/helper.py config option 'data_node_access_ips' and restart manila service
3. Add access-allow with ip type and value (controller node IP) to above temp share(tmp_backup). e.g. '10.1.1.50'
4. Create another share (e.g. share1) of 1GB, mount it, write some data to share. We will take backup of this share into tmp_backup in next steps.
5. openstack share backup create share1 --name backup1
6. mount tmp_backup and check the content. It should be same as data added in step4.
7. unmount tmp_backup. Mount share1, delete its data and unmount it.
8. openstack share backup restore backup1
9. Mount share1 and and check the content. It should be same as data added in step6
10. unmount share1
11. openstack share backup delete backup1.

thanks for your change.
i have some question about this,

1: This means that even though we backed up twice and both backup1 and backup2 are available, backup1 is already overwritten by backup2, and the user who uses backup1 to restore will inevitably have an undesirable result.
Can we create a backup_id_1 directory to backup share1 data and a backup_id_2 directory to backup share2 data after tmp_backup is mounted? This way, you can back up multiple shares without affecting each other. The size of tmp_backup can be set to 1TB as the total size of the backup pool.

In this way, both scenarios can be solved, what do you think?

1. yes, in this case previous data will be overwritten. Since both share are backed up on same location, latest copy will survive.

2. Yes, data copy in this case fails. But if share of 2G contains data less that 1G, it will work. Since during backup or migration, we copy actual content. But if share of 2G contain e.g. 1.2G data, then backup on tmp_backup of 1GB will fail.

Hi, Bailey, Scott and Davlet
Please help to review+2.

Is there a use-case which requires the drivers to be updated in the initramfs? Recall we are trying to limit the occasions we are updating the initramfs since it is a significant cost to storage. This should only be done if the drivers are required to boot the system, otherwise the drivers should only be updated in the rootfs.
Thank Vefa to explain.  yes it is correct because ostree rootfs is read-only, we can not use depmod to switch drivers.  So we must switch it in initramfs.
Thanks to Vefa for answering the question.

Sorry, that caused the confuse. That means repo ostree/initramfs-ostree will not need further modification for new/different driver package releases that are integrated into StarlingX in the future.
drivers must be added to initramfs to support multi-drivers.

I have the same question, why do nic drivers have to be in initramfs at all?  I can understand having the initramfs hosting disk drivers so that the root disk can get mounted, but shouldn't the nic drivers then be subsequently loaded from the root disk?  Am I missing something?

Hi Mark and Jim,

If my recollection is correct, there is some history behind the decision to have the NIC driver version switch logic in the initramfs for Debian-based StarlingX.

Jiping, correct me if I am wrong, but I think it had to do with the inability to modify the root file system (due to ostree) to persistently add a /etc/depmod.d/... file to be able to change the precedence/priority of different ice/iavf/i40e bundle versions, so that the desired version would be used with every reboot.

(I can attempt to find an internal bug report reference to support this. Let me try that; I may or may not be right.)

In CentOS-based StarlingX, the depmod.d approach was at least initially taken with small/minimal impact on the initramfs, whereas with Debian-based StarlingX, the initramfs-based approach *had* to be taken.

Now, this is what I remember, but I wish Jiping had explained this in detail.

Thank you,

Vefa

From the commit log in the review "This way, the initramfs will not need further modifications for new/different driver package releases that are integrated into StarlingX in the future."

So am I missing something? The initramfs should *only* be updated if it needs modifications to gain access to the rootfs. This will not mean that it never gets updated, but it will be rare.

OK. Based on the additional information provided by Vefa pointing at the limitations of driver selection given a read-only rootfs due to Ostree we can mark this line of comments as resolved. Obviously there are competing requirements which force our hand, the biggest and original problem in my mind being the need to support multiple driver versions. The size impact is only somewhat in our control and if size becomes a bigger priority than driver versions, then we can revisit this, but until then it is what it is.

We switch the different drivers in initramfs.  so we need put them to initramfs.
Please refer https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/integ/+/863204

Okay, I was close. The limitation was as follows:

After creating a file in /etc/depmod.d/... to be able to select a specific version of ice/iavf/i40e, one has to run "depmod", which naturally needs to write to /lib/modules/<kver>/... This is not possible with ostree, as the root file system is read-only. This is why the initramfs approach was taken.

I will send the internal bug report to the participants of this code review.

I don't know what to say, that text is completely misleading. This will need to be corrected as we need the initramfs to rarely be updated as it has a large size cost for the ostree commit. The only drivers that should be in the initramfs are those required to load and pivot to the rootfs, this did require some network drivers to enable network install via redfish but the multidriver should be relegated to after the pivot to the init on the rootfs and thus reside in the rootfs, not the initramfs.

I found the commit message a little confusing.

how about something like:

  Delete s3api MPU segments when expiring the manifest

  s3api MPU segments will be automatically deleted by the 
  expirer when it expires an s3api manifest.

  This is just a best effort cleanup of the segments. In some 
  circumstances (e.g. when manifest objects are not consistent)
  this may fail to delete all segments. However, s3api MPUs 
  already have a related bug to address orphaned segments.

  The automatic deletion is only applied to s3api segments, 
  not to SLO segments in general, because:

  (a) s3api segments cannot be referenced via the S3 API, and are 
      therefore orphaned as soon as the manifest is deleted; SLO 
      segments in general are not necessarily orphaned when a 
      manifest is deleted.

 (b) the names of s3api MPU segments can be easily inferred from 
     the manifest DELETE response headers without inspecting the 
     manifest body.

Now patch file name does not match what gets created by git format-patch.  One must use git format-patch to generate patches and then not rename the resulting file except to add/change/remove the leading number.  One must never directly edit patch files, that is a recipe for screw up.  Always use git format-patch after changing the commit via eg. git commit --amend

2 more issues:

1. Quotes around the variable will cause an error
2. Times are in ms not seconds

This is what I ended up with, to set TTL to 10 minutes and queue expiration to 20, for all "notifications" queues:

{"vhost": "/", "name": "notifications-expire", "pattern": "^(notifications|versioned_notifications).*", "apply-to": "queues", "definition": {"message-ttl":{{ rabbitmq_message_ttl }},"expires":{{ rabbitmq_queue_expire }}}, "priority":0},

And in ansible/roles/rabbitmq/defaults/main.yml:

rabbitmq_message_ttl: 60000
rabbitmq_queue_expire: 120000

I thought that I had correctly applied different policies to different sets of queues. Here's my entire policy section. I believe that this should exclude HA from the following:

1. Queues starting with "notifications" or "versioned_notifications"
2. Queues starting with "amq."
3. Queues with "_fanout_" anywhere in the name
4. Queues starting with "reply_"

Also it should apply TTL/expiration only to queues starting with "notifications" or "versioned_notifications"

The third line is the original "murano_agent" HA; I'm not sure what that does so I left it alone.

Am I missing something?

  "policies":[
    {"vhost": "/", "name": "notifications-expire", "pattern": "^(notifications|versioned_notifications).*", "apply-to": "queues", "definition": {"message-ttl":{{ rabbitmq_message_ttl }},"expires":{{ rabbitmq_queue_expire }}}, "priority":0},
    {"vhost": "/", "name": "ha-all", "pattern": "^(?!(amq\.)|(.*_fanout_)|(reply_)).*", "apply-to": "all", "definition": {"ha-mode":"all","ha-sync-mode":"automatic", "ha-promote-on-shutdown": "always" , "ha-promote-on-failure": "always"}, "priority":0}{% if project_name == 'outward_rabbitmq' %},
    {"vhost": "{{ murano_agent_rabbitmq_vhost }}", "name": "ha-all", "pattern": ".*", "apply-to": "all", "definition": {"ha-mode":"all"}, "priority":0}
    {% endif %}
  ]
}

It looks like a quote is missing:

{"vhost": "/", "name": "ttl", "pattern": ".*", "apply-to": "queues", "definition": {"message-ttl":{{ rabbitmq_message_ttl | int }}","expires":3600}, "priority":0},

Should be:

{"vhost": "/", "name": "ttl", "pattern": ".*", "apply-to": "queues", "definition": {"message-ttl":"{{ rabbitmq_message_ttl | int }}","expires":3600}, "priority":0},
Much less sure about this last one at the moment.

This change may disable the `ha-all` policy, as only one can apply to a queue or exchange. Consider altering the existing policies instead of creating another.

"Each exchange or queue will have at most one policy matching" - https://www.rabbitmq.com/parameters.html#how-policies-work

I will abandon this patch guys. After fixing the issue here, we found others. Such as, the migration of the actions to mistral_extra, which changed the command classes from mistral.actions.nova to mistra_extra.action.nova, and so on. 

Furthermore, even after amending that for testing, more errors appeared when the refactoring to introduce action providers was made. It seems that a migration path was not designed, and the code is not prepared to handle the legacy action definition in the database. We created our action definition with Mistral from Rocky release.

We concluded that it would be too much work to fix the compatibility. Therefore, right now, we are testing cleaning everything and recreating from scratch 😞


Still, we found more problems, such as always using the latest microversion possible. Before  those changes, mistral used the minimum microversion. This is a huge issue for us (and probably others), as we do upgrade on a component base (I know that most organziations do upgrade everything together, but it does not make sense when we have isolated systems integratins via APIs with microversions featureset). Therefore, we have the most different components running together, and when using Mistral now, it forces us to use always the latest versions.

The work around for that is to patch the Mistral containers with lower python clients that have the maximum microversion as the version of our APIs.

I am just registering these information here because if somebody else faces this situation, they already have some lead on how to proceed.
